Query: How do I find out what filesystem my partitions are using?

Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_510046: How do I find which disk/partition current directory is on?
ul_85624: Figuring out what OS is on which partition?
ul_436227: How to find out how many physically mounted filesystems there are?
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_436227: findmnt -t $(grep -v nodev /proc/filesystems | paste -sd, - | tr -d \\t)

findmnt -n -t $(grep -v nodev /proc/filesystems | paste -sd, - | tr -d \\t) | wc -l

Explanations about Options.--output:
Define output columns. See the --help output to get a list of the currently
 supported columns. The TARGET column contains tree formatting if the --list or
 --raw options are not specified.
Explanations about Options.-t:
Limit the set of printed filesystems. More than one type may be specified in a
 comma-separated list. The list of filesystem types can be prefixed with no to
 specify the filesystem types on which no action should be taken. For more details
 see mount(8).
Explanations about Options.--target:
Define the mount target. If path is not a mountpoint file or directory, then
 findmnt checks the path elements in reverse order to get the mountpoint (this
 feature is supported only when searching in kernel files and unsupported for
 --fstab). It's recommended to use the option --mountpoint when checks of path
 elements are unwanted and path is a strictly specified mountpoint.
Explanations about Options.-n: Do not print a header line.
Explanations about Options.--noheadings: Do not print a header line.

Top-3 Scripts: ul_342744: sudo fdisk -l 2>/dev/null | egrep "Disk /|/dev/" | sed "s#^/dev/#Part /dev/#" | awk '{print $2}' | sed 's/://' | xargs -n1 -IX sudo sh -c "hexdump -v -s 0x80 -n  2 -e '2/1 \"%x\" \"\\n\"' X | xargs -n1 -IY sh -c \"case  \"Y\" in '48b4') echo X: GRUB 2 v1.96 ;; 'aa75' | '5272') echo X: GRUB Legacy ;; '7c3c') echo X: GRUB 2 v1.97 oder v1.98 ;; '020') echo X: GRUB 2 v1.99 ;; *) echo X: Kein GRUB Y ;; esac\""

Explanations about Options.-l:
List the partition tables for the specified devices and then exit. If no devices
 are given, those mentioned in /proc/partitions (if that file exists) are used.

ul_191821: Find what process implements a FUSE filesystem
ul_146080: How do I find out what filesystem drivers are compiled-in into the linux kernel?

Explanations about Options.-t:
The argument following the -t is used to indicate the filesystem type. The
 filesystem types which are currently supported depend on the running kernel. See
 /proc/filesystems and /lib/modules/$(uname -r)/kernel/fs for a complete list of the
 filesystems. The most common are ext2, ext3, ext4, xfs, btrfs, vfat, sysfs, proc,
 nfs and cifs.

Answers.MP Summary: adjust tunable filesystem parameters on ext2/ext3/ext4 filesystems

Explanations about Options.-l:
List the contents of the filesystem superblock, including the current values of the
 parameters that can be set via this program.
